problem_text: 20.12. Let us say that a group G has the unique n-fold product property (u.-n-p.) if for every n-tuple of finite nonempty subsets A1, . . . , An ⊆ G there exists g ∈ G which can be written in one and only one way as g = a1 · · · an with ai ∈ Ai. It is easy to see that u.-n-p. implies u.-m-p. for n ⩾ m (since some of the Ai can be {1}). Are the conditions u.-n-p. (n ⩾ 2) all equivalent to u.-2-p., the usual unique product condition? G. M. Bergman
